_header: By sapience temper thy courage / Of hasty ire…
_description: Seven Wise Counsels — nine stanzas rhyme royal

BodAsh59.First Lines:
Bi sapience tempre þy courageOf hasty yre daunte þy
                    passiounsSuffre vengeance to þy wrath aswayeReverence þe
                    goode and þeire condiciouns…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…With hole herte body wille and myndeTo be contente with suche
                    as þey fynde
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here nowe foloweþe þe doctryne of many gret Clerkes approved made
                    in baladewyse and translated oute of divers langages in to englisshe (f.
                        70v); Doctrynes of wisdame (RT)
BodAsh59.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “Kleine Mitteilungen zur mittelenglische Lehrdichtung, VI.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         104 (1900): 293-309: 299-301.

CULFf16.First Lines:
By sapience tempre thy courageOf hasty Ire davnte thy
                    passionsDifferre vengeance tyl thy wrathe aswageReuerence the goode
                    for thayre condicions…
CULFf16.Last Lines:
…With hole hert body wyll and myndeTo be content with suche as
                    they fynde
CULFf16.Note:
Headings ‘Prudencia’, ‘Iusticia’,
                    ‘Temporancia’, ‘Discrecion’, ‘Reson’,
                    ‘Plesance Goode Wille’, and ‘Curtesie Nature’ above
                    stanzas.
CULFf16.Facsimiles:
Beadle,  Richard,  and  Alfred E. B. Owen.  
             The Findern Manuscript: Cambridge University Library MS. F.1.6.
         London: Scolar Press, 1977.

BLAru168.First Lines:
By sapience tempe þi corageOf hasty ire dawnt þi
                    passions…
BLAru168.Last Lines:
…With hoole hert body wille and myndeTo be content with suche
                    as þe may fynde
BLAru168.Note:
Names of seven virtues as headings to the seven stanzas, beginning
                    ‘Prudencia’ and ending ‘Curtesy &
                    Norture’.

BLHar116.First Lines:
By sapience tempere thy corageOf hasty Ire dawnte thy
                    passions…
BLHar116.Last Lines:
…With hole herte body wylle & myndeTo be content with
                    suche as they fynde

BLHar2251.First Lines:
BY sapience tempire thy corageOf hasty Ire daunt thy
                    passiouns…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…With hole hert body wille and myndeTo be content with suche
                    as ye fynde

Wellcome673.Editions:
Kane,  George. 
             “The Middle English Verse in MS Wellcome 1493.” 
             London Medieval Studies
         2, Part. I (1951): 50-67: 60-1.

YaleBei365.First Lines:
…Thynges passyd Remembrans and wyll devideThynges present
                    consydris and wyll gounne…
YaleBei365.Last Lines:
…The lordes that desyreth to be honourabyllCheresh your folke
                    and hat extorcion…
YaleBei365.Note:
Ends incomplete; only four stanzas on Prudencia, Iusticia,
                        Temperancia, and first two lines of Fortitudo.
YaleBei365.Editions:
Smith,  Lucy Toulmin,
                        ed.  
             A Commonplace Book of the Fifteenth Century.
         Norwich: Kerrison, Goose, 1886: 18-20.
Smith,  Lucy Toulmin,
                        ed.  
             “Notes on A Common-Place Book of the Fifteenth Century with a Religious
                Play of Abraham and Isaac.” 
             The Norfolk Antiquarian Miscellany.
            Walter Rye, ed. 
         3 vols. Norwich: Goose & Co, 1873-87: 3.115-67: 153-4.
